Author: tlrobinson
Content:
Could be web crawlers for search engines (or research, at Purdue?)

They're supposed to play nicely, especially if you have a robots.txt file set up. Try that first if you don't.

Author: raghus
Title: Ask PG: Qn on the 'More' link at the bottom of News.YC's home page
Content:
It changes with each page refresh now: from http://news.ycombinator.com/x?fnid=D5S0Tu4VK5 to http://news.ycombinator.com/x?fnid=ARW2OBvB6s... while pointing to posts 1-30. Any reason you are doing this?

Similarly, the More link at the bottom of Page 2 also changes each time but still points to Posts 31-60. And so on....

I think that at one time, the URL used to be just /page2 or something easily guessable.

Author: PStamatiou
Title: Ask YC: Dealing with DDoS
Content:
How do you do it?

At least once a week my load averages will stay at 5 or higher for about 30 minutes at a time. It's mysql that's eating up all the cycles even though page caching is setup for frequently accessed pages. netstat shows many blocks of IPs, each trying to connect to port 80 many times. I think it's coming from a zombie computer network.. one set of IPs included a Purdue connection.

My CS friends have told me about things ranging from iptables and manually adding offenders to my firewall - any automatic solutions that append offending IPs after X connections?

thanks

Author: bayareaguy
Content:
There is PythonCard: http://pythoncard.sourceforge.net/

Unfortunately it doesn't appear to be updated recently.

Author: rms
Content:
Not a YC company; the article says self-funded.

-

The company rates you post-interview, and one of the things they rate you on is how seriously you took the interview. So, basically, they can't weed out people just doing it for the money, as long as the person takes the interview seriously and acts professionally. Regardless, I think this is a good idea, it will definitely work as a self-funded company.

Today I find it a little ironic for any guy (including coding horror's blogger) who's running on Windows (or OS X) by choice to be bitching about freedom 0.

Author: atlacatl
Content:
The first thing that you should know and accept is that there are probably 10 other people working on the same application you have in mind or are working on.

Second, if you go the facebook route, the first app of its kind will likely be more successful--that incumbency thing. If it's a compeling app, hurry app and deploy it.

Finally, if you decide to create the website first, then your target market has to be well defined, i.e., you have a niche solution to a specific problem for a specific group of people. If it's too broad, creating the website first will not likely generate enough traction, unless you can create enough volume.

Author: scw
Content: Don't want to start a 'my database is...' rant, but have you given Postgres a whirl with said data?  It tends to be fairly robust for very large datasets, and its performance tends to be excellent under these conditions.  Migration from MySQL is straightforward; I use both DBs in separate environments.
